case_id: State of Tamil Nadu v. N. Suresh Rajan (2014) 11 SCC 709
facts: N. Suresh Rajan (Respondent No. 1/Accused No. 1 - A1) was a Member of the Legislative Assembly (MLA) of Tamil Nadu from 13.05.1996 to 13.05.2001.
During this period, he also served as the Minister for Khadi, Animal Husbandry, Milk and Dairy Development Corporation.

The Directorate of Vigilance and Anti-Corruption (DVAC), Nagercoil Detachment, registered an FIR (RC No. 5 of 2002) against A1 and others under Section 13(2) read with 13(1)(e) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988 (PC Act) and Section 109 IPC.

The allegation was that A1, during the check period (13.05.1996 to 13.05.2001), acquired assets disproportionate to his known sources of income in his name and the names of his relatives (Accused Nos. 2 to 7 - A2 to A7).
The charge sheet was filed on 15.05.2006 before the Special Judge/Chief Judicial Magistrate, Tirunelveli.

A1 filed a discharge petition (Crl. M.P. No. 1910 of 2006) primarily arguing that: (a) An MLA is not a 'public servant' under Section 2(c) of the PC Act, (b) No valid sanction under Section 19 of the PC Act was obtained for his prosecution.

The Special Judge dismissed the discharge petition on 06.01.2007, holding that an MLA is a public servant and sanction was not required as A1 had ceased to be an MLA/Minister when cognizance was taken.
A1 filed a Criminal Revision Petition (Crl. R.C. No. 216 of 2007) before the Madurai Bench of the Madras High Court.

The High Court, by its order dated 30.04.2012, allowed the revision petition and discharged A1, holding that an MLA is a public servant, but sanction under Section 19 PC Act was necessary even if the accused ceased to hold office, relying on *R.S. Nayak v. A.R. Antulay* (1984) and distinguishing *Prakash Singh Badal v. State of Punjab* (2007).
The State of Tamil Nadu appealed the High Court's order to the Supreme Court.
Respondents 2-7 (A2-A7) were relatives of A1, accused of abetting the offence under Section 109 IPC read with PC Act sections.

prosecution_arguments.argument: Sanction under Section 19 of the PC Act is not required for prosecuting a former public servant (ex-MLA/Minister) for offences committed during their tenure, as the accused did not hold the office at the time of cognizance.
precedents: Prakash Singh Badal v. State of Punjab (2007) 1 SCC 1
L. Narayana Swamy v. State of Karnataka (2016) 9 SCC 598 (Though later, affirms the principle followed here)
Abhay Singh Chautala v. CBI (2011) 7 SCC 141
elements: Accused was a public servant at the time of the offence.
Accused ceased to be a public servant at the time cognizance was taken.
Interpretation of Section 19 PC Act - focusing on the status 'at the time of cognizance'.

counter_arguments.loophole: The offence is intrinsically linked to the office held; therefore, the protection of sanction should extend even after demitting office if the act was committed *qua* public servant.
supporting_precedents: R.S. Nayak v. A.R. Antulay (1984) 2 SCC 183 (Interpreted by HC in respondent's favour)
Kalicharan Mohapatra v. State of Orissa (1998) 6 SCC 411 (Suggests sanction needed if offence relates to previous office, though later clarified)
Nanjappa v. State of Karnataka (2015) 14 SCC 186 (Discusses object of sanction relating to acts during office)

prosecution_arguments.argument: An MLA is a 'public servant' within the meaning of Section 2(c) of the PC Act, 1988.
precedents: P.V. Narasimha Rao v. State (CBI/SPE) (1998) 4 SCC 626
R.S. Nayak v. A.R. Antulay (1984) 2 SCC 183
Habibulla Khan v. State of Orissa (1995) 2 SCC 437
elements: Definition of 'public servant' under Section 2(c) PC Act.
Whether MLA falls under any sub-clause of Section 2(c).

counter_arguments.loophole: The definition of 'public servant' requires a direct employer-employee relationship or performance of specific public duties enumerated, which might not squarely fit the role of an MLA.
supporting_precedents: State of Gujarat v. Manshankar Prabhashankar Dwivedi (1972) 2 SCC 392 (Discusses nature of public duty)
R.S. Nayak v. A.R. Antulay (1984) 2 SCC 183 (While holding MLA is a public servant, the reasoning was debated and could be distinguished based on specific PC Act version)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Sufficient prima facie evidence exists in the charge sheet to frame charges under Section 13(1)(e) read with 13(2) PC Act against A1 and Section 109 IPC read with PC Act sections against A2-A7.
precedents: State of M.P. v. S.B. Johari (2000) 2 SCC 57
State of Maharashtra v. Som Nath Thapa (1996) 4 SCC 659
elements: Assets held by A1 or on his behalf by A2-A7.
Failure to satisfactorily account for assets.
Abetment by A2-A7 in acquiring/holding assets.

counter_arguments.loophole: The calculation of disproportionate assets by the prosecution may be flawed, ignoring legitimate sources of income or overvaluing assets/undervaluing income.
supporting_precedents: Krishnanand Agnihotri v. State of M.P. (1977) 1 SCC 816
State of Maharashtra v. Wasudeo Ramchandra Kaidalwar (1981) 3 SCC 199
M. Krishna Reddy v. State Dy. Superintendent of Police, Hyderabad (1992) 4 SCC 45

defense_arguments.argument: Sanction under Section 19 PC Act is mandatory as the alleged offence was committed while A1 was an MLA/Minister, and the prosecution is based on acts performed in that capacity, irrespective of his status at the time of cognizance.
edge_cases: Interpretation of 'is employed' vs. 'was employed' in Section 19 PC Act.
Applicability of R.S. Nayak v. A.R. Antulay (1984) over Prakash Singh Badal (2007).
precedents: R.S. Nayak v. A.R. Antulay (1984) 2 SCC 183
Kalicharan Mohapatra v. State of Orissa (1998) 6 SCC 411 (As interpreted by defense)
State Inspector of Police v. Surya Sankaram Karri (2006) 7 SCC 172 (Discusses nexus between act and office for sanction)

defense_arguments.argument: An MLA does not fit the definition of 'public servant' under Section 2(c) of the PC Act, 1988, as they are elected representatives, not 'employed' in connection with the affairs of the Union or State.
edge_cases: Distinguishing MLA's role from traditional government employment.
Whether P.V. Narasimha Rao case applies directly post PC Act 1988 amendments.
precedents: R.S. Nayak v. A.R. Antulay (1984) 2 SCC 183 (Although it held MLA is a public servant, defense might argue the reasoning is specific to the older PC Act 1947 or distinguishable)

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly exercised its revisional jurisdiction to quash the proceedings based on the legal bar of lack of sanction, preventing an abuse of process.
edge_cases: Scope of revisional power under Section 397/482 CrPC when a pure question of law (sanction) is involved.
Whether discharge is appropriate when sanction is deemed necessary but absent.
precedents: State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal 1992 Supp (1) SCC 335 (Guidelines for quashing FIR/charge sheet)
Dilawar Babu Kurane v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 2 SCC 135 (Principles for discharge)
R.S. Nayak v. A.R. Antulay (1984) 2 SCC 183 (Cognizance without sanction is void ab initio)

judgment.outcome: Appeal allowed. The Supreme Court set aside the High Court's order and restored the Trial Court's order dismissing the discharge petition. The prosecution against N. Suresh Rajan and others was allowed to proceed.
reasoning: The Court definitively held that an MLA is a 'public servant' under Section 2(c)(viii) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988, reaffirming the position in *P.V. Narasimha Rao v. State* and *R.S. Nayak v. A.R. Antulay*.

The primary issue decided was the requirement of sanction under Section 19 PC Act. The Court analyzed the language 'is employed' in Section 19(1) and contrasted it with the language 'was employed' used elsewhere.

The Court followed the precedent set in *Prakash Singh Badal v. State of Punjab (2007)* and *Abhay Singh Chautala v. CBI (2011)*, holding that sanction under Section 19 PC Act is not required if the public servant has ceased to hold the office (demitted office) which he is alleged to have abused, at the time of taking cognizance of the offence.

The Court explicitly distinguished the observations in *R.S. Nayak v. A.R. Antulay (1984)*, stating that the relevant observations were made in the context of the PC Act, 1947, and the specific wording of Section 19 of the PC Act, 1988, mandates focusing on the status of the accused at the time of cognizance.
Since N. Suresh Rajan was not an MLA or Minister when cognizance was taken by the Special Court in 2006, no sanction was required for his prosecution.
The High Court erred in relying on *R.S. Nayak* and ignoring the later, more direct precedents like *Prakash Singh Badal* concerning the interpretation of Section 19 of the PC Act, 1988.
The dismissal of the discharge petition by the Trial Court was correct in law.
